Primary goal: Using resources from nature more sustainably and efficiently
From Indicator: C10 Productive seas: fish and shellfish stocks safe and environmentally sustainable
To Indicator: E9 Percentage of our seafood coming from healthy ecosystems, produced sustainably
Rationale: E9 will use the data collected for the management of fish stocks to assess whether harvesting rates remain within sustainable limits (as shown in C10).

Primary goal: Using resources from nature more sustainably and efficiently
From Indicator: E1 Area of productive agricultural land
To Indicator: E7 Soil health
Rationale: Agricultural production and the associated land use and management are key drivers of the environmental impacts from the sector.

Primary goal: Using resources from nature more sustainably and efficiently
From Indicator: E1 Area of productive agricultural land
To Indicator: D1 Quantity, quality and connectivity of habitats
Rationale: As well as being vital for food production, agriculture helps to shape the landscape, providing important recreational, spiritual and other cultural benefits.

Primary goal: Using resources from nature more sustainably and efficiently
From Indicator: E1 Area of productive agricultural land
To Indicator: D1 Quantity, quality and connectivity of habitats
Rationale: As well as being vital for food production, agriculture helps to shape the landscape, providing important recreational, spiritual and other cultural benefits.

Primary goal: Using resources from nature more sustainably and efficiently
From Indicator: E2 Volume of agricultural production
To Indicator: E7 Soil health
Rationale: Agricultural production and the associated land use and management are key drivers of the environmental impacts from the sector.

Primary goal: Using resources from nature more sustainably and efficiently
From Indicator: E2 Volume of agricultural production
To Indicator: A2 Emissions of greenhouse gases from natural resources
Rationale: A2 includes greenhouse gas emissions from agriculture as a component in the graph (approximately 30% of total emissions).

Primary goal: Using resources from nature more sustainably and efficiently
From Indicator: E3 Volume of inputs used in agricultural production
To Indicator: A1 Emissions for five key air pollutants
Rationale: Agricultural sources make up by far the largest component in the inventory for Ammonia emissions with cattle manure management, manure applied to soils and inorganic fertilizers each accounting for 20% or more of the emissions from this sector. Agriculture also contributes a small proportion to NMVOC and PM2.5 emissions.

Primary goal: Using resources from nature more sustainably and efficiently
From Indicator: E3 Volume of inputs used in agricultural production
To Indicator: A2 Emissions of greenhouse gases from natural resources
Rationale: A2 includes greenhouse gas emissions from agriculture as a component in the graph (~30% of total emissions). This includes emissions from the use of agricultural inputs.

Primary goal: Using resources from nature more sustainably and efficiently
From Indicator: E3 Volume of inputs used in agricultural production
To Indicator: A6 Exceedance of damaging levels of nutrient nitrogen deposition on ecosystems
Rationale: Agricultural sources make up by far the largest component in the inventory for Ammonia emissions with cattle manure management, manure applied to soils and inorganic fertilizers each accounting for 20% or more of the emissions from this sector.

Primary goal: Using resources from nature more sustainably and efficiently
From Indicator: E3 Volume of inputs used in agricultural production
To Indicator: A7 Area exposed to damaging levels of ammonia (NH3) in the atmosphere
Rationale: Agricultural sources make up by far the largest component in the inventory for Ammonia emissions with cattle manure management, manure applied to soils and inorganic fertilizers each accounting for 20% or more of the emissions from this sector.

Primary goal: Using resources from nature more sustainably and efficiently
From Indicator: E3 Volume of inputs used in agricultural production
To Indicator: B1 Pollution loads entering waters
Rationale: B1 tracks changes in the inputs and discharges of selected contaminants such as nutrients and some toxic chemicals to rivers or directly to the sea, for example through activities such as agriculture inputting substances directly.

Primary goal: Using resources from nature more sustainably and efficiently
From Indicator: E3 Volume of inputs used in agricultural production
To Indicator: B2 Serious pollution incidents to water
Rationale: Agriculture is now the largest sector responsible for significant pollution events to water.

Primary goal: Using resources from nature more sustainably and efficiently
From Indicator: E3 Volume of inputs used in agricultural production
To Indicator: B3 State of the water environment
Rationale: Agriculture and rural land management is one of the main activities that prevent water bosies reaching good status.

Primary goal: Using resources from nature more sustainably and efficiently
From Indicator: E3 Volume of inputs used in agricultural production
To Indicator: B6 Natural functions of water and wetland ecosystems
Rationale: Nutrient run off affects the natural functions of wetland ecosystems, for example, through eutrophication.

Primary goal: Using resources from nature more sustainably and efficiently
From Indicator: E3 Volume of inputs used in agricultural production
To Indicator: D1 Quantity, quality and connectivity of habitats
Rationale: Farm practices and the use of inputs (particularly fertilisers and pesticides) directly influence the environmental pressures from farming including the quality, composition and availability of habitats.

Primary goal: Using resources from nature more sustainably and efficiently
From Indicator: E3 Volume of inputs used in agricultural production
To Indicator: D4 Relative abundance and distribution of widespread species
Rationale: D4 shows the decline of certain species groups on farmland.

Primary goal: Using resources from nature more sustainably and efficiently
From Indicator: E3 Volume of inputs used in agricultural production
To Indicator: D5 Conservation status of our native species
Rationale: Farm practices and the use of inputs (particularly fertilisers and pesticides) directly influence the environmental pressures from farming including the quality, composition and availability of habitats.

Primary goal: Using resources from nature more sustainably and efficiently
From Indicator: E3 Volume of inputs used in agricultural production
To Indicator: D6 Abundance and distribution of priority species in England
Rationale: Farm practices and the use of inputs (particularly fertilisers and pesticides) directly influence the environmental pressures from farming including the quality, composition and availability of habitats.

Primary goal: Using resources from nature more sustainably and efficiently
From Indicator: E3 Volume of inputs used in agricultural production
To Indicator: D7 Species supporting ecosystem functions
Rationale: Pesticide use affects pollinators.

Primary goal: Using resources from nature more sustainably and efficiently
From Indicator: E3 Volume of inputs used in agricultural production
To Indicator: E2 Volume of agricultural production
Rationale: Inputs include fertilisers and pesticides used to increase volume of agricultural production.

Primary goal: Using resources from nature more sustainably and efficiently
From Indicator: E3 Volume of inputs used in agricultural production
To Indicator: E7 Soil health
Rationale: The E7 indicator will include chemical properties (such as soil carbon, nutrients and pH) which are affected by inputs used.

Primary goal: Using resources from nature more sustainably and efficiently
From Indicator: E4 Efficiency of agricultural production measured by Total Factor Productivity
To Indicator: E1 Area of productive agricultural land
Rationale: Smaller amount of land required for same output from agricultural production if efficiency increased.

Primary goal: Using resources from nature more sustainably and efficiently
From Indicator: E4 Efficiency of agricultural production measured by Total Factor Productivity
To Indicator: E2 Volume of agricultural production
Rationale: Smaller amount of land required for same output from agricultural production if efficiency increased.

Primary goal: Using resources from nature more sustainably and efficiently
From Indicator: E5 Percentage of the annual growth of trees in English woodlands that is harvested
To Indicator: E6 Volume of timber brought to market each year
Rationale: Volume of timber brought to market will include timber harvested from English woodlands.

Primary goal: Using resources from nature more sustainably and efficiently
From Indicator: E7 Soil health
To Indicator: D4 Relative abundance and distribution of widespread species
Rationale: Healthy soils underpin the multiple functions of soils in supporting wildlife.

Primary goal: Using resources from nature more sustainably and efficiently
From Indicator: E7 Soil health
To Indicator: D5 Conservation status of our native species
Rationale: Healthy soils underpin the multiple functions of soils in supporting wildlife.

Primary goal: Using resources from nature more sustainably and efficiently
From Indicator: E7 Soil health
To Indicator: D6 Abundance and distribution of priority species in England
Rationale: Healthy soils underpin the multiple functions of soils in supporting wildlife.

Primary goal: Using resources from nature more sustainably and efficiently
From Indicator: E7 Soil health
To Indicator: D7 Species supporting ecosystem functions
Rationale: Healthy soils underpin the multiple functions of soils in supporting wildlife.

Primary goal: Using resources from nature more sustainably and efficiently
From Indicator: E7 Soil health
To Indicator: E2 Volume of agricultural production
Rationale: Healthy soils underpin the multiple functions of soils in food production.

Primary goal: Using resources from nature more sustainably and efficiently
From Indicator: E7 Soil health
To Indicator: F1 Disruption or unwanted impacts from flooding or coastal erosion
Rationale: Healthy soils underpin the multiple functions of soils in regulating water.

Primary goal: Using resources from nature more sustainably and efficiently
From Indicator: E8 Sustainable use of water
To Indicator: B5 Water bodies achieving sustainable abstraction criteria
Rationale: Reducing water consumption and leakage will help in achieving sustainable extraction.

Primary goal: Using resources from nature more sustainably and efficiently
From Indicator: E8 Sustainable use of water
To Indicator: F3 Disruption or unwanted impacts caused by drought
Rationale: Reducing water consumption and leakage will mitigate the impacts of drought.

Primary goal: Using resources from nature more sustainably and efficiently
From Indicator: J2 Raw material consumption
To Indicator: J1 Carbon footprint and consumer buying choices
Rationale: Raw materials are used in the production of goods measured by J1.

Primary goal: Using resources from nature more sustainably and efficiently
From Indicator: J2 Raw material consumption
To Indicator: E6 Volume of timber brought to market each year
Rationale: Raw material consumption includes biomass products such as timber.

Primary goal: Using resources from nature more sustainably and efficiently
From Indicator: A4 Rural background concentrations of ozone (O3)
To Indicator: E2 Volume of agricultural production
Rationale: Ozone can have adverse effects on the environment through oxidative damage to vegetation.

Primary goal: Using resources from nature more sustainably and efficiently
From Indicator: A6 Exceedance of damaging levels of nutrient nitrogen deposition on ecosystems
To Indicator: E7 Soil health
Rationale: Excess deposition of NH3 on natural ecosystems causes nutrient enrichment and changes in vegetation and soils.

Primary goal: Using resources from nature more sustainably and efficiently
From Indicator: C2 Seabed subject to high pressure from human activity
To Indicator: C11 Productive seas: status of sensitive fish and shellfish stocks
Rationale: C11 will show the status of fish and shellfish that are particularly sensitive to pressures such as fishing mortality. C2 shows level of pressure from some types of fishing.

Primary goal: Using resources from nature more sustainably and efficiently
From Indicator: D3 Area of woodland in England
To Indicator: E5 Percentage of the annual growth of trees in English woodlands that is harvested
Rationale: Source data for E5 includes National Forest Inventory forecasts of increase (increment) in the volume of wood that grows in England, which incorporate information on woodland area.

Primary goal: Using resources from nature more sustainably and efficiently
From Indicator: D3 Area of woodland in England
To Indicator: E1 Area of productive agricultural land
Rationale: In some situations, increase in woodland area will reduce the area of productive agricultural land.

Primary goal: Using resources from nature more sustainably and efficiently
From Indicator: D7 Species supporting ecosystem functions
To Indicator: E2 Volume of agricultural production
Rationale: D7 shows trends in pollinators which are important for crop production.

Primary goal: Using resources from nature more sustainably and efficiently
From Indicator: G6 Environmental attitudes and behaviours
To Indicator: E8 Sustainable use of water
Rationale: G6 will include information on peopleâ€™s self-reported environmental behaviours, likely including questions on water use.

Primary goal: Using resources from nature more sustainably and efficiently
From Indicator: H2 Distribution of invasive non-native species and plant pests and diseases
To Indicator: E2 Volume of agricultural production
Rationale: H2 includes tree pests that affect crops, such as Sweet chestnut blight.

Primary goal: Using resources from nature more sustainably and efficiently
From Indicator: J2 Raw material consumption
To Indicator: E6 Volume of timber brought to market each year
Rationale: Raw material consumption includes biomass products such as timber.
